results.title: 16mm Prints
results.brief_description:
1. Granville Cattle Shoot - Unedited footage of bulldozers and men clearing land in order to create pens to house cattle. Cattle is then shot in the head and picked-up by a bulldozer/tractor that dumps the dead, or close to dead body in a pit with other bloodied carcases. The pit of dead cows is then filled with soil.

  2. Mice Milking - Documents the process in which scientists at Dandenong milk mice with special machinery. The milk is then given to the American Cancer Council who use it to research cancer treatment. A mouse attached to the milking machine looks quite bizarre. One mouse yeilds a third of a teaspoon of milk per milking session. Good footage of the machine in action.

  3. The problem of Lamb Survival - Shows how the Department of Agriculture is trying to improve the amount of lambs that are born each year and survive to adulthood. Includes footage of a mobile laboratory in the field.

  4. N.A.S.A moon shots - Filmed photographs of general space imagery, focusing on the moon and spacecraft. Contains photograph or earth from space.

  5. Eclipse 23/10/76’ - Rushes of countryside, sheep and cars in the day and at night.

results.title: Beautiful lies: a film about Peter Carey
results.creator_credit: Don Featherstone, Australian Film Commission and Australia Council
results.brief_description: Peter Carey is one of Australia’s most talented writers. All four of his published works have won major literary awards. This film, takes a journey through his life and work and looks at the way he transforms his native country into a bizarre land of nightmares and surreal comedy. Throughout the film, an interview with Peter Carey is interwoven with lavish dramatisation. An intriguing and illuminating film about a remarkable writer.
results.title_for_label: Beautiful lies: a film about Peter Carey
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Featherstone, Australian Film Commission and Australia Council

results.title: 'A'
results.creator_credit: Argos Films Borresholm, Jan Lenica and Renate Duhr
results.brief_description: A bitter, pessimistic cartoon, showing man’s utter helplessness in the face of forces stronger than himself. A man’s home is invaded by the letter “A”. Guile, flattery, magic, brute strength fail to remove this enemy. He gives up all hope - then discovers that “A” has disappeared. After a period of doubt he is delighted to be alone again. Suddenly “B” appears! In fine line pen-and-ink style reminiscent of 19th century engraving, Jan Lenica has created a visual joke based on one of Eugene Ionesco’s quotations. The letters also symbolise privacy, oppression or one’s own problems. (Awards: Grand Prize for Film Animation, Oberhausen Festival)

constellations_primary.name: Suburban scenes (Lisa McCune)
constellations_primary.description: Lisa McCune is best known for her role as Constable Maggie Doyle in the television series Blue Heelers (1994–2006). In addition to showing the day-to-day lives of police in a small Victorian town, the series explores the various dynamics of suburbia—a theme present throughout the whole of screen media.

results.title: Cyberthon III: The Underground Connection [1-hour compilation]
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon III: The Underground Connection’ was the third broadcast event in the Cyberthon series, held at TVU’s (Television Unlimited) warehouse and studio in Footscray Victoria. Increasing again in scope and complexity from Cyberthon II, Cyberthon III collaborators invited ten local bands, ten local DJ’s and 3RRR radio hosts Kate Bathgate and Liz Miller to interview artists and participants live at the event. This was in addition to the extensive DJ and VJ sets, live artist performances, electronic art and installations on displays. Viewers were also encouraged to interact with participating artists via a bulletin board system (BBS) or fax in a Cyberthon event first.

This one-hour compilation was created a month after the event from nine hours of footage and subsequently aired July 12, 1992.

Visual Artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Dale Nason and Troy Innocent), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi), Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Video Graffiti (Andrew Nelson)

Audio Artists: Darren Jackson (Geeza), Braden Schlager & Miles du Heaume (1x4x9), Soulscraper (Chris Dubrow, Sarah Lord, James Lynch, Elanor Rayner & Jim Shnookal), H2o (Terence Ho ), Vertigo Hypo (Bryan St James & Narelle Wellington), 2120 (Claude Young Jr), Hardware (Richie ‘Rich’ McNeil), Poets of the Machine (Coral and Stripe), The Visitor (Andrew Till), Liz Millar, This Digital Ocean (Liz Millar, Ross Healy & Simon Bowley), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac), Miss Baby Lemonade Lemarr (Andrea), Mish Fingers (Misha Hollenbach), Whip (Kent Morris, Michelle, Mirella, Simon), Geeza (Darren Jackson), Wesley McDonald

Performers: Tranzmission (Kate Bathgate), Liz Millar, Every Picture Tells a Story (Hydi John), Central Station (Joe Polumbo), Yoga (Mary Galick, Eugene-NRG (Paul Gafney) & Bronwyn Richie), Mad Club (Bernie Grogan, Danny Slim, Susan Clinch & Matt the Tree), Taz (Tasilim Emiabata), Star (Raquel Webb), Lizette Broulathaki and Jynell Dolan.

results.title: Woman in a house
results.brief_description: One of Sue Ford’s earliest films, “Woman in a house” is a feminist critique of domestic female roles. In this short film, a young woman in a suburban house escapes the confinement of her life through surreal dream sequences created with experimental montage techniques. Made in 1972, the film was shown at screenings run by the Melbourne Filmmaker’s Co-op and was one of the most popular films available to rent from the feminist film collective Reel Women, of which Ford was a founding member, in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

results.title: Michelle Yeoh wins Best Actress at Oscars 2023: ‘Beacon of hope’
results.credit_line: Recorded from New York Post’s Youtube Chanel
results.material_description: Screen recording from New York Post's YouTube channel
results.brief_description: Michelle Yeoh described her win for Best Actress as a beacon of hope for Asian audiences everywhere. In an Oscar’s first, Yeoh became the first Asian woman to win the award in its history, only the second woman of color to take home that award ever. Halle Berry, the first WOC to win in the same category over 20 years ago, presented the award
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Michelle Yeoh described her win for Best Actress as a beacon of hope for Asian audiences everywhere. In an Oscar’s first, Yeoh became the first Asian woman to win the award in its history, only the second woman of color to take home that award ever. Halle Berry, the first WOC to win in the same category over 20 years ago, presented the award.
description_for_label:

In an Oscar’s first, Yeoh became the first Asian woman to win the award in its history, only the second woman of color to take home that award ever. Halle Berry, the first WOC to win in the same category over 20 years ago, presented the award.

results.title: Melbourne: festival city
results.creator_credit: Gordon C. Lloyd, Tourist Development Authority of Victoria and Cinesound
results.brief_description: Melbourne’s Moomba festival - the city comes alive with processions, regattas, the Herald open air art show, music under the stars at the Myer Music Bowl, and the crowning of the Moomba Queen. The film also shows some of the Melbourne landscape and the background of daily life; Melbourne’s economic expansion; the Melbourne Cup, the race for which the nation stands still; Australian Rules Football, drawing crowds of over 50,000; fine golf courses; hunting; night life. It closes with a coverage of the Moomba procession, with all its varied floats, including the Bunyip and the Chinese dragon.
